message:
I have been doing some research on Dramatica's Plot Progression; the Signposts and Journeys, and how they are used as a framework for scenes. 4 Signposts, 3 Journeys, altogether 7 aspects of each throughline.

Can these be seen directly as 7 steps? If so, could it be used as a comparison to say, Truby's 7 step approach to structure, taking into the Dramatica throughline focus here?

Or should I not see this as 7 steps? I remember reading that writers should use either the Signposts or the Journeys. Does that mean using both is not recommended? 

I'm curious because I can see the logic in dividing a story into 7 steps, as a precursor to a step / scene outline.

As for me I prefer to just look at the signposts and construct the story from there. I think that in the writing process the Journeys will show up naturally. The Audience will synthesize these Journeys as well.
You can do whatever you want as long as it makes your story better
FWIW, I try to jot down my journeys to see if I can, but I don't really focus on them either.
Thanks. I wasn't sure if using them as 7 steps was going against some aspect of how the plot progression was designed to help structure.
